Looking Back: Midterm in two weeks [1/23]

  • You have three hours (3:00) to take the exam.
  • If a question is unclear or ambiguous, write down your assumptions.
  • The exam is closed book and closed notes.
  • You may consult one letter-size page (front and back) of notes that you have prepared.
  • Write your answers on the exam. If I can not read your answer clearly, it will be marked as incorrect.
  • You will find some information on Java APIs, junit, and design patterns at the end of the exam.
  • When drawing UML class diagrams, follow these guidelines:
    • Be specific (prefer aggregation and dependency to association, prefer composition to aggregation).
    • Show mutiplicities on aggregations and compositions.
    • Be careful with arrowheads and with dashed/solid lines.
    • Clearly distinguish classes and interfaces.
    • Clearly indicate static classes.
Here is a syllabus for the exam.

+ UML Object Diagrams
  - objects (fields with value)
  - relations
    * link

+ UML Interaction Diagrams
  - objects (lifetime) (also static classes)
  - method/constructor call (lifetime and arguments)
  - method/constructor return (value)

+ UML Class Diagrams
  - classes (fields and methods with type and visibility)
  - interfaces (methods with type and visibility)
  - big arrow relations (triangular arrowhead)
    * specialization
    * realization
  - small arrow relations
    * aggregation
    * composition
    * dependency

+ Simple Idioms and OO programming techniques (using java)
  - packages
  - interfaces
  - classes
  - constructors
  - delegation
  - inner classes
  - static versus object classes
  - immutable data classes
  - mutable data classes
  - data object methods (equals, hashCode, compareTo, ...)
  - collection classes

+ Patterns
  - static factory
  - builder
  - command
  - strategy
  - state
  - composite

Looking Back: OO Mechanisms [2/23]

Interface: Primitive for describing the type or interface of an object.

Class: Primitive for describing implementation of an object.

Constructor: Primitive construct for building objects.

Delegation: (Partial) responsibility for a message is given to another object.

Subclassing: (Partial) responsibility for a message is given to a class other than the actual class of the object. [Not covered on midterm, except with respect to Object]

Looking Back: Basic Concepts [3/23]

Immutable Data Class: Unchanging data (eg, String).

Mutable Data Class: Changing data (eg, an Employee class that contains salary information).

Collection Class: A collection. May be mutable or immutable.

Looking Back: System Architecture [4/23]

MVC lite: Separate IO from business logic.

Looking Back: Controlling the number of instances [5/23]

Static Class: A set of global variables and functions.

Looking Back: Creating instances [6/23]

Static Factory: a static class whose purpose is to generate instances of an interface (or interfaces). The interface and factory are public, but the implementing classes are not.

Builder: A mutable object used to build an immutable object. Add pieces to the builder gradually, then convert to its immutable representation (eg, StringBuilder).

Looking Back: Structuring Behavior [7/23]

Command: Encapsulate a function as an object. The command can then be accessed from many places. It may also support undo/redo.

Strategy: Encapsulate variation into a separate object. A method accesses the variation (strategy) by delegating to a field or parameter.

State: Create the illusion that an object changes its actual type (using delegation to a field). A nice way to eliminate case statments.

Looking Back: Collections [8/23]

Composite: Make collections of objects have the same interface as single objects.

Composite: Example [12/23]

I will discuss these notes.

file:composite/one/Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package composite.one;
00002: public class Main {
00003:   public static void main(String[] args) {
00004:     Expr one = new Const(1);
00005:     Expr onePtwo = new Plus (new Const(1), new Const(2));
00006:     Expr threeMfour = new Mult (new Const(3), new Const(4));
00007:     Expr m = new Minus (onePtwo, threeMfour);
00008:     Expr n = new Quot (m, new Const(5));
00009: 
00010:     System.out.println(n);
00011:     System.out.println("Value: " + n.eval());
00012:   }
00013: }
00014:

file:composite/one/Expr.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package composite.one;
00002: public interface Expr {
00003:   int eval();
00004: }
00005: 
00006: final class Const implements Expr {
00007:   private final int _v;
00008:   public Const(int v) {
00009:     _v = v;
00010:   }
00011:   public int eval() {
00012:     return _v;
00013:   }
00014:   public String toString() {
00015:     return Integer.toString(_v);
00016:   }
00017: }
00018: 
00019: final class Plus implements Expr {
00020:   private final Expr _l;
00021:   private final Expr _r;
00022:   public Plus(Expr l, Expr r) {
00023:     if ((l == null) || (r == null)) {
00024:       throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00025:     }
00026:     _l = l;
00027:     _r = r;
00028:   }
00029:   public int eval() {
00030:     return _l.eval() + _r.eval();
00031:   }
00032:   public String toString() {
00033:     return _l.toString() + " " + _r.toString() + " +";
00034:   }
00035: }
00036: 
00037: final class Minus implements Expr {
00038:   private final Expr _l;
00039:   private final Expr _r;
00040:   public Minus(Expr l, Expr r) {
00041:     if ((l == null) || (r == null)) {
00042:       throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00043:     }
00044:     _l = l;
00045:     _r = r;
00046:   }
00047:   public int eval() {
00048:     return _l.eval() - _r.eval();
00049:   }
00050:   public String toString() {
00051:     return _l.toString() + " " + _r.toString() + " -";
00052:   }
00053: }
00054: 
00055: final class Mult implements Expr {
00056:   private final Expr _l;
00057:   private final Expr _r;
00058:   public Mult(Expr l, Expr r) {
00059:     if ((l == null) || (r == null)) {
00060:       throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00061:     }
00062:     _l = l;
00063:     _r = r;
00064:   }
00065:   public int eval() {
00066:     return _l.eval() * _r.eval();
00067:   }
00068:   public String toString() {
00069:     return _l.toString() + " " + _r.toString() + " *";
00070:   }
00071: }
00072: 
00073: final class Quot implements Expr {
00074:   private final Expr _l;
00075:   private final Expr _r;
00076:   public Quot(Expr l, Expr r) {
00077:     if ((l == null) || (r == null)) {
00078:       throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00079:     }
00080:     _l = l;
00081:     _r = r;
00082:   }
00083:   public int eval() {
00084:     return _l.eval() / _r.eval();
00085:   }
00086:   public String toString() {
00087:     return _l.toString() + " " + _r.toString() + " /";
00088:   }
00089: }

Composite: Variations [13/23]

  • Using a static factory
  • Refactor to strategy (binary operations all have same form)
  • nary ops. What if Plus and Mult take any number of operands? Need an add method on the composite.
  • Using Builder for nary ops
  • Mutable Composites
    • put add in interface
    • use two interfaces

Composite: With a static factory [14/23]

file:composite/two/Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package composite.two;
00002: public class Main {
00003:   public static void main(String[] args) {
00004:     Expr one = ExprFactory.newConst(1);
00005:     Expr onePtwo = ExprFactory.newPlus
00006:       (ExprFactory.newConst(1), ExprFactory.newConst(2));
00007:     Expr threeMfour = ExprFactory.newMult
00008:       (ExprFactory.newConst(3), ExprFactory.newConst(4));
00009:     Expr m = ExprFactory.newMinus (onePtwo, threeMfour);
00010:     Expr n = ExprFactory.newQuot (m, ExprFactory.newConst(5));
00011: 
00012:     System.out.println(n);
00013:     System.out.println("Value: " + n.eval());
00014:   }
00015: }

file:composite/two/ExprFactory.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package composite.two;
00002: public class ExprFactory {
00003:   private ExprFactory() {}
00004:   static public Expr newConst(int v) {
00005:     return new Const(v);
00006:   }
00007:   static public Expr newPlus(Expr l, Expr r) {
00008:     return new Plus(l, r);
00009:   }
00010:   static public Expr newMinus(Expr l, Expr r) {
00011:     return new Minus(l, r);
00012:   }
00013:   static public Expr newMult(Expr l, Expr r) {
00014:     return new Mult(l, r);
00015:   }
00016:   static public Expr newQuot(Expr l, Expr r) {
00017:     return new Quot(l, r);
00018:   }
00019: 
00020:   private static class Const implements Expr {
00021:     private final int _v;
00022:     public Const(int v) {
00023:       _v = v;
00024:     }
00025:     public int eval() {
00026:       return _v;
00027:     }
00028:     public String toString() {
00029:       return Integer.toString(_v);
00030:     }
00031:   }
00032: 
00033:   private static class Plus implements Expr {
00034:     private final Expr _l;
00035:     private final Expr _r;
00036:     public Plus(Expr l, Expr r) {
00037:       if ((l == null) || (r == null)) {
00038:         throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00039:       }
00040:       _l = l;
00041:       _r = r;
00042:     }
00043:     public int eval() {
00044:       return _l.eval() + _r.eval();
00045:     }
00046:     public String toString() {
00047:       return _l.toString() + " " + _r.toString() + " +";
00048:     }
00049:   }
00050: 
00051:   private static class Minus implements Expr {
00052:     private final Expr _l;
00053:     private final Expr _r;
00054:     public Minus(Expr l, Expr r) {
00055:       if ((l == null) || (r == null)) {
00056:         throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00057:       }
00058:       _l = l;
00059:       _r = r;
00060:     }
00061:     public int eval() {
00062:       return _l.eval() - _r.eval();
00063:     }
00064:     public String toString() {
00065:       return _l.toString() + " " + _r.toString() + " -";
00066:     }
00067:   }
00068: 
00069:   private static class Mult implements Expr {
00070:     private final Expr _l;
00071:     private final Expr _r;
00072:     public Mult(Expr l, Expr r) {
00073:       if ((l == null) || (r == null)) {
00074:         throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00075:       }
00076:       _l = l;
00077:       _r = r;
00078:     }
00079:     public int eval() {
00080:       return _l.eval() * _r.eval();
00081:     }
00082:     public String toString() {
00083:       return _l.toString() + " " + _r.toString() + " *";
00084:     }
00085:   }
00086: 
00087:   private static class Quot implements Expr {
00088:     private final Expr _l;
00089:     private final Expr _r;
00090:     public Quot(Expr l, Expr r) {
00091:       if ((l == null) || (r == null)) {
00092:         throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00093:       }
00094:       _l = l;
00095:       _r = r;
00096:     }
00097:     public int eval() {
00098:       return _l.eval() / _r.eval();
00099:     }
00100:     public String toString() {
00101:       return _l.toString() + " " + _r.toString() + " /";
00102:     }
00103:   }
00104: }

Composite: Refactor to Strategy [15/23]

file:composite/three/ExprFactory.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package composite.three;
00002: 
00003: public class ExprFactory {
00004:   private ExprFactory() {}
00005:   static public Expr newConst(int v) {
00006:     return new Const(v);
00007:   }
00008:   static public Expr newPlus(Expr l, Expr r) {
00009:     return new BinOp(l, new OpAdd(), r);
00010:   }
00011:   static public Expr newMinus(Expr l, Expr r) {
00012:     return new BinOp(l, new OpSub(), r);
00013:   }
00014:   static public Expr newMult(Expr l, Expr r) {
00015:     return new BinOp(l, new OpMul(), r);
00016:   }
00017:   static public Expr newQuot(Expr l, Expr r) {
00018:     return new BinOp(l, new OpDiv(), r);
00019:   }
00020: 
00021:   private static final class Const implements Expr {
00022:     private final int _v;
00023:     public Const(int v) {
00024:       _v = v;
00025:     }
00026:     public int eval() {
00027:       return _v;
00028:     }
00029:     public String toString() {
00030:       return Integer.toString(_v);
00031:     }
00032:   }
00033:   
00034:   private static final class BinOp implements Expr {
00035:     private final Expr _l;
00036:     private final Expr _r;
00037:     private final Op _op;
00038:     public BinOp(Expr l, Op op, Expr r) {
00039:       if ((l == null) || (op == null) || (r == null)) {
00040:         throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00041:       }
00042:       _op = op;
00043:       _l = l;
00044:       _r = r;
00045:     }
00046:     public int eval() {
00047:       return _op.eval(_l.eval(), _r.eval());
00048:     }
00049:     public String toString() {
00050:       return _l.toString() + " " + _r.toString() + " " + _op.toString();
00051:     }
00052:   }
00053: 
00054:   private static interface Op {
00055:     public abstract int eval(int x, int y);
00056:   }
00057:   private static final class OpAdd implements Op {
00058:     public String toString() { return "+"; }
00059:     public int eval(int x, int y) { return x+y; }
00060:   }
00061:   private static final class OpSub implements Op {
00062:     public String toString() { return "-"; }
00063:     public int eval(int x, int y) { return x-y; }
00064:   }
00065:   private static final class OpMul implements Op {
00066:     public String toString() { return "*"; }
00067:     public int eval(int x, int y) { return x*y; }
00068:   }
00069:   private static final class OpDiv implements Op {
00070:     public String toString() { return "/"; }
00071:     public int eval(int x, int y) { return x/y; }
00072:   }
00073: }
00074: 
00075:

Composite: N-ary Ops [16/23]

file:composite/four/Main.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package composite.four;
00002: public class Main {
00003:   public static void main(String[] args) {
00004:     Expr onePtwo = ExprFactory.newPlus
00005:       (ExprFactory.newConst(1), ExprFactory.newConst(2));
00006:     
00007:     ExprBuilder eb = ExprFactory.newMultBuilder(); 
00008:     eb.add(ExprFactory.newConst(3));
00009:     eb.add(ExprFactory.newConst(4));
00010:     eb.add(onePtwo);
00011:     Expr multiplies = eb.toExpr();
00012:     Expr m = ExprFactory.newMinus (onePtwo, multiplies);
00013: 
00014:     System.out.println(m);
00015:     System.out.println("Value: " + m.eval());
00016:   }
00017: }
00018:

file:composite/four/ExprBuilder.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package composite.four;
00002: public interface ExprBuilder {
00003:   Expr toExpr();
00004:   void add(Expr e);
00005: }
00006:

file:composite/four/ExprFactory.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package composite.four;
00002: import java.util.List;
00003: import java.util.LinkedList;
00004: 
00005: public class ExprFactory {
00006:   private ExprFactory() {}
00007:   static public Expr newConst(int v) {
00008:     return new Const(v);
00009:   }
00010:   static public Expr newPlus(Expr l, Expr r) {
00011:     return new BinOp(l, new OpAdd(), r);
00012:   }
00013:   static public Expr newMinus(Expr l, Expr r) {
00014:     return new BinOp(l, new OpSub(), r);
00015:   }
00016:   static public Expr newMult(Expr l, Expr r) {
00017:     return new BinOp(l, new OpMul(), r);
00018:   }
00019:   static public Expr newQuot(Expr l, Expr r) {
00020:     return new BinOp(l, new OpDiv(), r);
00021:   }
00022:   static public ExprBuilder newPlusBuilder() {
00023:     return new NaryOpBuilder(new OpAdd(), new Const(0));
00024:   }
00025:   static public ExprBuilder newMultBuilder() {
00026:     return new NaryOpBuilder(new OpMul(), new Const(1));
00027:   }
00028: }
00029: 
00030: final class Const implements Expr {
00031:   private final int _v;
00032:   public Const(int v) {
00033:     _v = v;
00034:   }
00035:   public int eval() {
00036:     return _v;
00037:   }
00038:   public String toString() {
00039:     return Integer.toString(_v);
00040:   }
00041: }
00042:   
00043: final class BinOp implements Expr {
00044:   private final Expr _l;
00045:   private final Expr _r;
00046:   private final Op _op;
00047:   public BinOp(Expr l, Op op, Expr r) {
00048:     if ((l == null) || (op == null) || (r == null)) {
00049:       throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00050:     }
00051:     _op = op;
00052:     _l = l;
00053:     _r = r;
00054:   }
00055:   public int eval() {
00056:     return _op.eval(_l.eval(), _r.eval());
00057:   }
00058:   public String toString() {
00059:     return _l.toString() + " " + _r.toString() + " " + _op.toString();
00060:   }
00061: }
00062: 
00063: final class NaryOp implements Expr {
00064:   private final Expr[] _args;
00065:   private final Expr _zero;
00066:   private final Op _op;
00067:   public NaryOp(Expr[] args, Op op, Expr zero) {
00068: // Don't need to test these, since the builder checks them.
00069: //     if ((args == null) || (op == null) || (zero == null))
00070: //       throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00071: //     for (int i=0; i<args.length; i++)
00072: //       if (args[i] == null)
00073: //         throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00074:     _op = op;
00075:     _args = args;
00076:     _zero = zero;
00077:   }
00078:   public int eval() {
00079:     int result = _zero.eval();
00080:     for (int i=0; i<_args.length; i++)
00081:       result = _op.eval(result, _args[i].eval());
00082:     return result;
00083:   }
00084:   public String toString() {
00085:     StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
00086:     sb.append("[");
00087:     for (int i=0; i<_args.length; i++) {
00088:       sb.append(_args[i].toString());
00089:       if (i+1<_args.length)
00090:         sb.append(", ");
00091:     }
00092:     sb.append("]");
00093:     sb.append(_op.toString());
00094:     sb.append(" ");
00095:     return sb.toString();
00096:   }
00097: }
00098: 
00099: final class NaryOpBuilder implements ExprBuilder {
00100:   private final List<Expr> _args;
00101:   private final Expr _zero;
00102:   private final Op _op;
00103:   public NaryOpBuilder(Op op, Expr zero) {
00104:     if ((op == null) || (zero == null))
00105:       throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00106:     _args = new LinkedList<Expr>();
00107:     _op = op;
00108:     _zero = zero;
00109:   }
00110:   public void add(Expr e) {
00111:     if (e == null)
00112:       throw new IllegalArgumentException();
00113:     _args.add(e);
00114:   }
00115:   public Expr toExpr() {
00116:     return new NaryOp(_args.toArray(new Expr[0]), _op, _zero);
00117:   }
00118: }
00119: 
00120: interface Op {
00121:   public abstract int eval(int x, int y);
00122: }
00123: final class OpAdd implements Op {
00124:   public String toString() { return "+"; }
00125:   public int eval(int x, int y) { return x+y; }
00126: }
00127: final class OpSub implements Op {
00128:   public String toString() { return "-"; }
00129:   public int eval(int x, int y) { return x-y; }
00130: }
00131: final class OpMul implements Op {
00132:   public String toString() { return "*"; }
00133:   public int eval(int x, int y) { return x*y; }
00134: }
00135: final class OpDiv implements Op {
00136:   public String toString() { return "/"; }
00137:   public int eval(int x, int y) { return x/y; }
00138: }
00139:

State: An example [17/23]

Remember the awful finite state machine from Homework 3?

file:Control.java [source]

Here is a version refactored to the state pattern:

file:Control.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.ui.main;
00002: 
00003: import state.ui.UI;
00004: import state.ui.UIMenu;
00005: import state.ui.UIMenuAction;
00006: import state.ui.UIMenuBuilder;
00007: import state.ui.UIForm;
00008: import state.ui.UIFormTest;
00009: import state.ui.UIFormBuilder;
00010: 
00011: class Control {
00012:   final State EXITED; 
00013:   final State EXIT; 
00014:   private State _state;
00015:   private UI _ui;
00016:   Control(UI ui) {
00017:     EXITED = new ExitedState();
00018:     EXIT = new ExitState(this,ui);
00019:     _ui = ui;
00020:     _state = EXIT;
00021:   }
00022:   
00023:   void run() {
00024:     while (_state != EXITED) {
00025:       _state = _state.run();
00026:     } 
00027:   }
00028: }
00029: 
00030: interface State {
00031:   public State run();
00032: }
00033: 
00034: final class ExitedState implements State {
00035:   public State run() {
00036:     return this;
00037:   }
00038: }
00039: 
00040: final class ExitState implements State {
00041:   Control _control;
00042:   UI _ui;
00043:   UIMenu _m;
00044:   ExitState(Control control, UI ui) {
00045:     _control = control;
00046:     _ui = ui;
00047: 
00048:     UIMenuBuilder m;
00049:     m = new UIMenuBuilder();
00050:     
00051:     m.add("Default", new UIMenuAction() { public Object run() {return this;} });
00052:     m.add("Yes",
00053:       new UIMenuAction() {
00054:         public Object run() {
00055:           return _control.EXITED;
00056:         }
00057:       });
00058:     m.add("No",
00059:       new UIMenuAction() {
00060:         public Object run() {
00061:           return _control.EXIT;
00062:         }
00063:       });
00064:     _m = m.toUIMenu("Are you sure you want to exit?");
00065:   }
00066:   public State run() {
00067:     return (State) _ui.processMenu(_m);
00068:   }
00069: }
00070:

Full code: dir:state/ui [source]

State: Initial code [19/23]

Discuss intrinsic/extrinsic state and field/parameter refactorings.

file:I.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.one;
00002: 
00003: interface I {
00004:   public int f();
00005:   public int g();
00006:   public void changeDirection();
00007: }
00008: 
00009: class C implements I {
00010:   private boolean _state;
00011:   private int _i;
00012:   private int _j;
00013:   public int f() {
00014:     if (_state)
00015:       _i += 26;
00016:     else
00017:       _i -= 32;
00018:     return _i;
00019:   }
00020:   public int g() {
00021:     if (_state)
00022:       _j += 42;
00023:     else
00024:       _j -= 27;
00025:     return _j;
00026:   }
00027:   public void changeDirection() {
00028:     _state = !_state;
00029:   }
00030: }
00031:

State: Refactored to state using inner class [20/23]

file:I.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.five;
00002: 
00003: interface I {
00004:   public int f();
00005:   public int g();
00006:   public void changeDirection();
00007: }
00008: 
00009: class C implements I {
00010:   private State _state = new StateMinus();
00011:   private int _i;
00012:   private int _j;
00013:   public int f() {
00014:     return _state.f();
00015:   }
00016:   public int g() {
00017:     return _state.g();
00018:   }
00019:   public void changeDirection() {
00020:     _state = _state.next();
00021:   }
00022: 
00023:   interface State {
00024:     public int f();
00025:     public int g();
00026:     public State next();
00027:   }
00028:   class StateMinus implements State {
00029:     public int f() {
00030:       _i -= 32;
00031:       return _i;
00032:   }
00033:     public int g() {
00034:       _j -= 27;
00035:       return _j;
00036:     }
00037:     public State next() {
00038:       return new StatePlus();
00039:     }
00040:   }
00041:   class StatePlus implements State {
00042:     public int f() {
00043:       _i += 26;
00044:       return _i;
00045:     }
00046:     public int g() {
00047:       _j += 42;
00048:       return _j;
00049:     }
00050:     public State next() {
00051:       return new StateMinus();
00052:     }
00053:   }
00054: }

file:I.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.four;
00002: 
00003: interface I {
00004:   public int f();
00005:   public int g();
00006:   public void changeDirection();
00007: }
00008: 
00009: class C implements I {
00010:   private CState _state = new CStateMinus(this);
00011:   int _i;
00012:   int _j;
00013:   public int f() {
00014:     return _state.f();
00015:   }
00016:   public int g() {
00017:     return _state.g();
00018:   }
00019:   public void changeDirection() {
00020:     _state = _state.next();
00021:   }
00022: }
00023: 
00024: interface CState {
00025:   public int f();
00026:   public int g();
00027:   public CState next();
00028: }
00029: class CStateMinus implements CState {
00030:   C _x;
00031:   CStateMinus(C x) { _x = x; }
00032:   public int f() {
00033:     _x._i -= 32;
00034:     return _x._i;
00035:   }
00036:   public int g() {
00037:     _x._j -= 27;
00038:     return _x._j;
00039:   }
00040:   public CState next() {
00041:     return new CStatePlus(_x);
00042:   }
00043: }
00044: class CStatePlus implements CState {
00045:   C _x;
00046:   CStatePlus(C x) { _x = x; }
00047:   public int f() {
00048:     _x._i += 26;
00049:     return _x._i;
00050:   }
00051:   public int g() {
00052:     _x._j += 42;
00053:     return _x._j;
00054:   }
00055:   public CState next() {
00056:     return new CStateMinus(_x);
00057:   }
00058: }
00059:

State: Refactored to state using parameter [22/23]

file:I.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.two;
00002: 
00003: interface I {
00004:   public int f();
00005:   public int g();
00006:   public void changeDirection();
00007: }
00008: 
00009: class C implements I {
00010:   private CState[] _states = new CState[] { new CStateMinus(), new CStatePlus() };
00011:   private int _index;
00012:   int _i;
00013:   int _j;
00014:   public int f() {
00015:     return _states[_index].f(this);
00016:   }
00017:   public int g() {
00018:     return _states[_index].g(this);
00019:   }
00020:   public void changeDirection() {
00021:     _index = (_index+1) % 2;
00022:   }
00023: }
00024: 
00025: interface CState {
00026:   public int f(C x);
00027:   public int g(C x);
00028: }
00029: class CStateMinus implements CState {
00030:   public int f(C x) {
00031:     x._i -= 32;
00032:     return x._i;
00033:   }
00034:   public int g(C x) {
00035:     x._j -= 27;
00036:     return x._j;
00037:   }
00038: }
00039: class CStatePlus implements CState {
00040:   public int f(C x) {
00041:     x._i += 26;
00042:     return x._i;
00043:   }
00044:   public int g(C x) {
00045:     x._j += 42;
00046:     return x._j;
00047:   }
00048: }

State: Refactored to state using parameter and single instances [23/23]

file:I.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.three;
00002: 
00003: interface I {
00004:   public int f();
00005:   public int g();
00006:   public void changeDirection();
00007: }
00008: 
00009: class C implements I {
00010:   private CState _state = CState.MINUS;
00011:   private int _index;
00012:   int _i;
00013:   int _j;
00014:   public int f() {
00015:     return _state.f(this);
00016:   }
00017:   public int g() {
00018:     return _state.g(this);
00019:   }
00020:   public void changeDirection() {
00021:     _state = (_state==CState.MINUS) ? CState.PLUS : CState.MINUS;
00022:   }
00023: }
00024: 
00025:

file:CState.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.three;
00002: 
00003: interface CState {
00004:   public int f(C x);
00005:   public int g(C x);
00006: 
00007:   public static final CState MINUS = new CStateMinus();
00008:   public static final CState PLUS = new CStatePlus();
00009: }
00010: 
00011: class CStateMinus implements CState {
00012:   public int f(C x) {
00013:     x._i -= 32;
00014:     return x._i;
00015:   }
00016:   public int g(C x) {
00017:     x._j -= 27;
00018:     return x._j;
00019:   }
00020: }
00021: class CStatePlus implements CState {
00022:   public int f(C x) {
00023:     x._i += 26;
00024:     return x._i;
00025:   }
00026:   public int g(C x) {
00027:     x._j += 42;
00028:     return x._j;
00029:   }
00030: }
00031:
